    ktk.cycles module¶

    Identify cycles and time-normalize data.

    Warning

    This module is in early development and may change in the future.

    Functions

    detect_cycles(ts, data_key, /, event_name1, …)

    Detect cycles in a TimeSeries based on a dual threshold approach.

    most_repeatable_cycles(data)

    Get the indexes of the most repeatable cycles in TimeSeries or array.

    stack_normalized_data(ts, /[, n_points])

    Stack time-normalized TimeSeries’s data into a dict of arrays.

    time_normalize(ts, /, event_name1, …[, …])

    Time-normalize cycles in a TimeSeries.
    ktk.cycles.detect_cycles(ts, data_key, /, event_name1, event_name2, raising_threshold, falling_threshold, *, min_length1=0, min_length2=0, target_height1=None, target_height2=None)¶

    Detect cycles in a TimeSeries based on a dual threshold approach.

    Warning

    This function is currently experimental and may change signature and behaviour in the future.

    This function detects biphasic cycles and identifies the transitions as new events in the output TimeSeries. These new events are named:

    • event_name1: corresponds to the start of phase 1

    • event_name2: corresponds to the start of phase 2

    • ‘_’: corresponds to the end of the cycle. Apart from the last cycle, this always coincides with the start of the next phase 1.

    Parameters

    • ts (TimeSeries) – TimeSeries to analyze.

    • data_key (str) – Name of the data key to analyze in the TimeSeries. This signal must be high during phase 1, and low during phase 2. For example, one could use the absolute ground reaction force to detect stance (phase 1) and swing (phase 2).

    • event_name1 (str) – Name of the events in the output TimeSeries that corresponds to the start of phase 1.

    • event_name2 (str) – Name of the events in the output TimeSeries that corresponds to the start of phase 2.

    • raising_threshold (float) – Value to cross upward to register the start of phase 1.

    • falling_threshold (float) – Value to cross downward to register the start of phase 2.

    • min_length1 (float) – Optional. Minimal time of phase 1 in seconds.

    • min_length2 (float) – Optional. Minimal time of phase 2 in seconds.

    • target_height1 (Optional[float]) – Optional. A value that the signal must cross in phase 1. Use None for no target height.

    • target_height2 (Optional[float]) – Optional. A value that the signal must cross in phase 2. Use None for no target height.

    Returns

    A copy of ts with the events added.

    Return type

    TimeSeries

    ktk.cycles.most_repeatable_cycles(data)¶

    Get the indexes of the most repeatable cycles in TimeSeries or array.

    Warning

    This function is currently experimental and may change signature and behaviour in the future.

    This function returns an ordered list of the most repeatable to the least repeatable cycles.

    Its algorithm is to recursively discards the cycle than maximizes the root-mean-square error between the cycle and the average of every remaining cycle, until there are only two cycles remaining. The function returns a list that is the reverse order of cycle removal: first the two last cycles, then the last-removed cycle, and so on. If two cycles are as equivalently repeatable, they are returned in order of appearance.

    Note

    Cycles that include at least one NaN are excluded.

    Parameters

    data (ndarray) – Stacked time-normalized data to analyze, in the shape (n_cycles, n_points).

    Returns

    List of indexes corresponding to the cycles in most to least repeatable order.

    Return type

    List[int]

    Example

    >>> import ktk, numpy as np
>>> # Create a data sample with four different cycles, the most different
>>> # begin cycle 2 (cos instead of sin), then cycle 0.
>>> x = np.arange(0, 10, 0.1)
>>> data = np.array([         [np.sin(x)],         [np.sin(x) + 0.14],         [np.cos(x) + 0.14],         [np.sin(x) + 0.15]])

    >>> ktk.cycles.most_repeatable_cycles(data)
[1, 3, 0, 2]
    ktk.cycles.stack_normalized_data(ts, /, n_points=100)¶

    Stack time-normalized TimeSeries’s data into a dict of arrays.

    Warning

    This function is currently experimental and may change signature and behaviour in the future.

    This methods returns the data of a time-normalized TimeSeries, reshaped to (n_cycles, n_points, …).

    Parameters

    • ts (TimeSeries) – The time-normalized TimeSeries.

    • n_points (int) – Optional. The number of points the TimeSeries has been time-normalized on.

    Returns

    Return type

    Dict[str, np.ndarray]

    ktk.cycles.time_normalize(ts, /, event_name1, event_name2, *, n_points=100)¶

    Time-normalize cycles in a TimeSeries.

    This method time-normalizes the TimeSeries at each cycle defined by event_name1 and event_name2 on n_points. The time-normalized cycles are put end to end. For example, for a TimeSeries that contains three cycles, a time normalization with 100 points will give a TimeSeries of length 300. The TimeSeries’ events are also time-normalized.

    To time-normalize a cycle between two events of the same name, use ‘_’ for event_name2. For example, to time-normalize a TimeSeries between each heel strike and the next heel strike:

    ktk.cycles.time_normalize(ts, ‘heelstrike’, ‘_’)

    Parameters

    • ts (TimeSeries) – The TimeSeries to analyze.

    • event_name1 (str) – The event name that correspond to the begin of a cycle.

    • event_name2 (str) – The event name that correspond to the end of a cycle.

    • n_points (int) – Optional. The number of points of the output TimeSeries.

    Returns

    A new TimeSeries where each cycle has been time-normalized.

    Return type

    TimeSeries
